terms.definition: Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted by a provider and accessed via the internet
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to access previous versions and see who made what changes
A chronological record of system activities that provides documentary evidence of the sequence of activities that have affected a specific operation or document
A single, unified location where all documents, files, or data are stored and can be accessed by authorized users from different departments or locations
The ability for multiple users to work on the same document or project simultaneously, with changes visible to all participants instantly
Pre-designed document formats that provide a standardized structure and layout for creating consistent documentation
The systematic monitoring and management of adherence to regulatory requirements, standards, and policies through documentation and reporting
Food and Drug Administration - the U.S. federal agency responsible for regulating and supervising the safety of food, drugs, and other consumer products
European Food Safety Authority - the European Union agency that provides independent scientific advice on food safety and risk assessment
The systematic process of creating, storing, organizing, and controlling access to documents throughout their lifecycle
The process of ensuring that an organization adheres to laws, regulations, guidelines, and specifications relevant to its business operations
The systematic evaluation of potential hazards and their likelihood of occurrence to determine appropriate safety measures and controls
The formal process of submitting required documentation to regulatory authorities to obtain approval for marketing and selling a product
The process of implementing and developing technical standards to ensure consistency, quality, and compatibility across documents or processes
